body.name: What Wild Women Do: A Novel

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #60,052 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #126 in Women's Detective Fiction #216 in Women's Crime Fiction #614 in Women's Historical Fiction

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book brought back lots of memories from the 60s & 70s women’s movement, something I think many of us need to revisit. The writing was excellent- clear yet descriptive. The story follows 2 women - one living in the 70s the other living post -Covid. I highly recommend this book it has a mystery, adventure and wisdom.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars a great read!
reviews.reviewText: Loved the back and forth in time, connection to nature, and acknowledgement of finding one’s inner strength. Very cool story, mystery, and ending!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Interesting and worthwhile read
reviews.reviewText: I had been waiting for quite some time for Karma Brown to publish a new novel under her own name again and What Wild Women Do did not disappoint.This novel explores the lives of two women from very different time periods and brings them together in a unique setting. I liked this story and getting to know Eddie and Rowan throughout. I never knew what was going to happen from one moment to the next and there were a lot of surprises in store as a result. I also loved the Adirondacks setting and how serene everything felt in nature.There was an element of suspense in wanting to find out how Eddie went missing, but I felt like it was anticlimactic when we learned what happened. The situation was tragic, but I was expecting something more from it.Overall, an interesting novel and a worthwhile read. Well done, Karma!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars What Wild Women Do
reviews.reviewText: I didn't know what to expect diving into this book, and I was pleased with the dual timelines and exploring nature. However, it took me a long time to get drawn into this book and I don't think I was ever fully engaged. There was a lot of build-up that I'm not sure was necessary. The end was nicely wrapped up.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Loved this book! I laughed, I cried! It was great!If you like feminism, birds, hiking, the 70s, and the film industry... You'll like this!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars LOVED this book
reviews.reviewText: This book has everything I love in a book. Great characters, original concept, fantastic writing, and a delicious story that kept me turning pages. Karma Brown does it again!!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars An Updated Betty Friedan
reviews.reviewText: OMG this book had me in tears by the end. It sparked so many memories of my own when growing up - wandering alone and happy in a forest near my home (which is now part of the D.C. Beltway), being taught to speak my mind, my own developing independence, the buzzsaw against the women's movement of the '70s, how today's sexist dinosaurs are still fighting us. I graduated college in 1975 and this book's story is set there. I read Betty Friedan's seminal call to action when it first came out. This book has been a wake up call for me now, at age 70. I am going to buy this book in hard copy and keep it. Thank you, Karma Brown.

reviews.reviewerName: Laura Mazzotta, LCSW-R, Author of Holistic Mental Health, Spiritual Therapist x 20 years
reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good Story Overall; Not Compelling
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed this read but it took me a little more time to get through it. Ultimately, I really appreciated the messages in this book but I didn’t feel engaged until over halfway through. Even then, it was interesting enough but I wasn’t dying to get back to it. I still have some remnants of the main character lingering, so there’s something there…

reviews.reviewTitle: an engaging story that sparks one to look within
reviews.reviewText: Love Karma Brown’s writing style and her talent in creating a twist to how story finishes and not a traditional, expected finish.
